abstracts.cdata!:
The Health and Nutrition Project's
            outcome was rated as satisfactory. The key lessons learned
            from the project include: 1) Project preparation should take
            account of project risks as comprehensively as possible and
            should reduce the complexity and extent of the project on
            the basis of the magnitude and probability of these risks.
            2) The relationship between IDA and the government during
            project negotiation should be weighed carefully. 3) The
            involvement of multiple agencies/ministries make project
            implementation more difficult. 4) Critical policy reforms
            should be pursued as project outcomes rather than upfront
            conditionalities. 5) Compliance to these covenants and
            conditionalities should be within the purview of the
            implementing agencies. 6) Project components should be
            designed with an internal logic behind them and not merely
            used as baskets to put activities in need of funding. 7)
            Economic liberalization and related macroeconomic reforms
            provide strong underpinnings for sector reforms and
            significantly enhance their achievement. 8) Baseline data
            and performance targets should be defined at project
            appraisal. 9) For skill-scarce countries or sectors,
            training should be conducted as soon as possible. 10)
            Counterpart funds should be calculated globally for the
            whole project, rather than on a contract-by-contract basis,
            and should take into account extra-budgetary resources
            generated from project-supported initiatives.
